content: How can I help you today?

I've been having a hard time sleeping lately. My head is always spinning with thoughts about work, bills, and just everything going on. My partner thought coming here might help, but honestly, I don't know if talking about it will change anything.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot of weight on your shoulders right now with work, finances, and other responsibilities. That can make it really tough to rest and sleep well. It’s understandable to wonder whether talking about it will help. What made your partner suggest coming here as a possible next step?

My partner said I’ve been really stressed and distant lately, and they’re worried about me. I think they just want me to find a way to deal with all of this because I’ve been feeling so overwhelmed. I don’t want to let them down, but I don’t even know where to start fixing things.

Your partner's concern for you shows how much they care, and it sounds like you’re also carrying a worry about not letting them down while managing your own feelings of overwhelm. It can feel daunting when you’re unsure where to begin, especially when the stress feels piled up. What’s been weighing on you the most lately?

I’d say work is the biggest one. I’m constantly worried about losing my job, especially with how the company’s been doing lately. If that happens, I don’t know how I’ll take care of my family. It just feels like there’s no room for mistakes right now, and that pressure is all I can think about.

That pressure sounds heavy, especially with the fear of what job uncertainty could mean for you and your family. Having such high stakes can make it hard to focus on anything else, and it's understandable that work is dominating your thoughts. How do you usually handle stressful situations like this?

Honestly, I haven’t been handling this one very well. I just keep replaying everything in my head, trying to figure out how to make sure I don’t mess up, but it’s exhausting. I’m not sure what else to do—it feels like there’s no way to stop the stress from taking over.

It sounds like you're stuck in a loop of constantly trying to be perfect at work to protect what matters most to you, and that cycle is leaving you emotionally drained. It's understandable to feel overwhelmed when the stakes feel so high. Have there been moments during all of this when you've found even a small sense of relief or calm?

Not really, to be honest. It feels like the stress follows me everywhere, even when I’m with my family or trying to relax. It’s like I can’t fully shut off my mind, and that just makes everything feel harder.

It sounds like no matter where you are, the stress is always present, making it difficult to find any real peace or escape. That can be incredibly exhausting, especially when you’re trying to enjoy time with your family or unwind. What do you think might need to change for you to feel less consumed by stress?

Maybe if I could feel more secure about my job or find a way to quiet the constant worrying, it would help. But I’m not sure how to get there. Everything just feels so uncertain right now, and it’s hard to imagine things getting better.

Feeling more secure about your job or finding a way to ease the constant worrying could make it easier to cope with everything you're facing. That uncertainty you're experiencing makes sense—it’s tough to imagine solutions when it feels so overwhelming. What would you say matters most to you as you think about what you’re going through right now?

What matters most to me is being able to provide for my family and be there for them, especially my kids. They’re my biggest priority, and I just want to make sure they’re taken care of, no matter what happens. It’s hard to focus on anything else when I feel like that’s at risk.

Your family is clearly so important to you, and your commitment to providing for them and being present shows how deeply you care. It makes sense that their well-being is at the forefront of your mind right now. In thinking about your priority to care for them, are there any small steps or changes you think could support both your needs and theirs?
Take your time; there's no rush. What you're feeling is valid, and it's okay to pause and reflect before thinking about any steps forward. Let me know what's coming to mind for you, if anything.

I’m not really sure. It’s hard to think about steps when everything already feels so overwhelming. I guess maybe finding a way to stop overthinking at night would help, so I can sleep and at least have more energy to deal with everything during the day.

Focusing on your sleep sounds like an important place to start—it could give you the energy to face the challenges ahead more effectively. Struggling with overthinking at night can make it hard to rest and recharge. Have you tried anything in the past to quiet your thoughts before bed?

No, not really. I usually just lie there, hoping I'll eventually fall asleep, but it doesn't work. Sometimes I try scrolling on my phone to distract myself, but that seems to make it worse. I feel like my brain won't shut off no matter what I do.

It sounds like lying there or using your phone hasn’t helped ease those racing thoughts, and you’re stuck in a cycle that doesn’t give you the rest you need. That constant mental activity can be draining, especially when you’re already dealing with so much. If calming your mind at night were possible, what do you think it might look like for you?
